channel.title: NPR Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Martínez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.

item.title: Iranian political analyst discusses latest talks with U.S. on a new nuclear deal
item.description: NPR's A Martínez speaks with Iranian political analyst Seyed Mohammad Marandi about the latest talks with the U.S. over a nuclear deal.

item.title: Attorney Theodore Boutrous discusses NPR's lawsuit against Trump White House
item.description: NPR's Michel Martin talks with attorney Theodore Boutrous, who is representing NPR in a legal challenge to Trump White House plans to stop federal funding of public media.

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: Rollout of U.S.-backed Gaza aid plan mired in chaos, federal government no longer recommends COVID vaccinations for healthy pregnant women and kids, U.S. works to extract kids held in Syrian camps.

item.title: Photographer Kip Fulbeck revisits 'The Hapa Project' 25 years after its launch
item.description: What does it mean to be "half"? Twenty-five years since its initial launch, photographer Kip Fulbeck revisits his exhibition called "The Hapa Project," an intimate look at mixed-race America.

item.title: Aid groups say USAID cuts are already having deadly consequences
item.description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio said at a hearing last week that no one has died from USAID cuts. But aid groups say abruptly shutting down those programs is having deadly consequences.

item.title: Remembering teacher and elder Marian Scott, one of the remaining Arapaho speakers
item.description: Revered teacher and culture keeper Marian Scott passed away this spring. She's one of fewer than 100 fluent speakers of the Arapaho language and will be missed on Wyoming's Wind River Reservation.

item.title: Lawsuit shuts down Montana clinic that helped people sickened by asbestos
item.description: Asbestos mining sickened generations of people in Libby, Montana. Now, a lawsuit has shut down a clinic set up to help them, even as others continue to be diagnosed.

item.title: U.S. officials criticize moves allowed by German constitution that U.S. helped shape
item.description: U.S. officials have criticized recent moves by the German government allowed under the German constitution, which the U.S. helped design.

item.title: Thousands of hungry people in Gaza overwhelm food distribution site
item.description: The start of a Israeli plan backed by the U.S. to control aid distribution in Gaza was mired in chaos on Tuesday. Dozens were shot by Israeli gunfire as crowds surged to where food was distributed.

item.title: Former Israeli PM Ehud Olmert says his country is committing war crimes in Gaza
item.description: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with former Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Olmert. In a recent article in the Israeli publication "Haaretz," he said his country is committing war crimes in Gaza.
